meta.title: Nonresidential Process Systems Compliance (PRC-E)
meta.authority: California Energy Commission — 2022 Energy Code (Title 24, Part 6)
meta.relevance: Required for nonresidential buildings with process loads (kitchens, refrigeration, labs, parking garages, elevators, etc.); common correction when process systems are not addressed in energy compliance documents

overview.description: The NRCC-PRC-E is the Certificate of Compliance for nonresidential process systems under the 2022 California Energy Code. It documents energy efficiency requirements for building systems that are not covered by standard HVAC, lighting, or envelope forms — primarily process loads like commercial kitchens, refrigeration, compressed air, labs, elevators, and industrial heat.
when_required: Nonresidential buildings containing any of the 19 listed process system categories
Restaurants and food service facilities (commercial kitchen ventilation, walk-in coolers/freezers, refrigerated warehouses)
Parking garages with ventilation or EV charging
Industrial/manufacturing with process heating or compressed air
Buildings with computer rooms or data centers
overview.who_completes: Design professional of record (engineer) responsible for the process systems
overview.submission_timing: Submitted with building permit application as part of the NRCC package

related_forms.description: Commissioning requirements — process systems must be included in Cx plan
Performance approach — process loads in whole-building energy model
Acceptance test form for process systems (field verification)

A_commercial_kitchen_ventilation.description: Commercial kitchen exhaust and makeup air systems

requirements.detail: Type I hoods for grease-laden vapor (cooking), Type II hoods for steam/heat/odor. Hood type determines required exhaust rate and makeup air configuration.
Exhaust rate shall not exceed values in Table 140.9-A based on hood type (wall-canopy, single island, double island, eyebrow, backshelf) and duty rating (light, medium, heavy, extra-heavy)
Transfer air shall be used before introducing outside air. Makeup air shall not exceed 90% of exhaust for Type I hoods. Replacement air must be conditioned or directly from outdoors.
Required for systems with total exhaust ≥5,000 CFM. Must reduce exhaust and makeup air by ≥50% during idle conditions based on optical, temperature, or smoke density sensors.
Hoods listed as 'efficient' by ASTM F3230 may use reduced exhaust rates per Table 140.9-B

A_commercial_kitchen_ventilation.sf_note: DBI and DPH both review kitchen ventilation. DPH requires health permit clearance for food service. Grease interceptor also required per DPW.

B_commercial_kitchen_refrigeration.description: Walk-in coolers and freezers for commercial kitchen use

requirements.detail: Walk-in cooler walls/ceilings: R-28 minimum. Walk-in freezer walls/ceilings: R-36 minimum. Floors: R-28 (coolers), R-36 (freezers) if conditioned space below.
All walk-in cooler and freezer doors shall have automatic door closers. Strip curtains or air curtains required on doorways ≥6 ft wide or frequently opened.
Evaporator fan motors shall be ECM or equivalent high-efficiency type
Anti-sweat heaters on cooler/freezer doors shall have automatic controls that reduce heater energy when not needed
Condensing units serving walk-in coolers/freezers shall use floating head pressure controls to reduce compressor energy at low ambient temperatures

C_refrigerated_warehouse.description: Refrigerated warehouse and distribution center systems

requirements.detail: Minimum insulation for cooler spaces: R-36 walls, R-36 ceiling. Freezer spaces: R-36 walls, R-46 ceiling. Higher insulation may be required by performance approach.
All openings shall have automatic closers, strip curtains, or air curtains. Loading docks shall have sealed loading dock shelters.
Ammonia systems ≥100 tons shall use evaporative condensers or equivalent with wet-bulb approach ≤15°F
Refrigeration systems ≥50 HP total compressor capacity shall have variable-speed or multiple staging capability
Variable-speed fan motors required on condenser fans for systems ≥3 HP total fan motor power

D_computer_rooms.description: Computer rooms and data center HVAC requirements

requirements.detail: Computer rooms with cooling capacity ≥3 tons must have air-side or water-side economizers capable of 100% cooling at outdoor conditions per Table 140.9-D
Supply fan system power shall not exceed the fan power allowances in Table 140.9-D based on system type and design airflow
Computer room cooling systems shall be capable of maintaining recommended ASHRAE TC 9.9 temperature ranges (64.4°F–80.6°F) without reheat
Supply airflow shall be variable to match load. Constant-volume systems are not permitted for computer rooms ≥10 tons cooling.
Enclosed parking garages shall have CO sensors to modulate ventilation. Sensors per Table 140.9-E: minimum 1 per 5,000 sq ft. Fan system must be capable of reducing airflow to 50% or less of design.
Garages with diesel vehicle traffic require NO2 sensors in addition to CO sensors
Garage exhaust fan motors ≥1 HP shall have VFD or ECM controls for variable speed operation

E_parking_garage_ventilation.sf_note: SF DBI mechanical plan check (M-06) specifically checks garage ventilation. SFFD also reviews for fire/smoke exhaust in enclosed garages.

F_compressed_air.description: Compressed air systems for manufacturing and industrial use

requirements.detail: Compressed air systems ≥25 HP total compressor capacity shall have load/unload, VSD, or inlet modulation controls
Systems ≥25 HP shall have a storage receiver sized to limit compressor cycling to manufacturer recommendations (typically 1 gallon per CFM)
System shall be designed for the lowest header pressure that meets process requirements. Pressure/flow controllers required for multi-compressor systems ≥50 HP.
Ultrasonic leak detection survey required within 1 year of occupancy for systems ≥100 HP

G_laboratory_exhaust.description: Laboratory fume hood and exhaust systems

requirements.detail: Laboratory fume hoods shall be VAV type with sash position sensors. Constant-volume hoods only permitted where required for safety by the chemical hygiene officer.
Lab exhaust systems with total exhaust ≥5,000 CFM shall have energy recovery with ≥50% enthalpy recovery effectiveness. Exceptions: corrosive or toxic exhaust where energy recovery is not feasible.
Where permitted by safety requirements, fume hoods shall be connected to a manifolded exhaust system with variable-speed fans rather than individual constant-volume fans.
Lab spaces shall reduce ventilation during unoccupied periods to minimum required for safety (typically 4 ACH occupied, 2 ACH unoccupied)

H_commercial_refrigeration.description: Commercial refrigeration display cases and systems (grocery/retail)

requirements.detail: Medium-temperature vertical display cases shall have doors. Open merchandisers only permitted for produce, deli, and floral displays.
Glass door display cases shall have anti-sweat heater controls that reduce heater power based on humidity conditions
Compressor suction pressure shall float up when cooling load decreases. Minimum floating range: 50% of design pressure differential.
Condenser pressure shall float down with ambient temperature. Required for systems ≥50 HP total compressor motor power.
Mechanical subcooling or liquid-suction heat exchange required for systems ≥100,000 Btu/h total capacity
Cab lighting shall be LED or equivalent high-efficacy source. When cab is unoccupied for >15 minutes, lighting and ventilation shall be reduced to ≤50%.
Elevators shall have standby mode that reduces energy consumption when the car is idle. Motor drives shall be capable of regenerative braking.

Escalators and moving walkways shall automatically reduce speed to ≤50% of design speed when no passengers are detected for ≥5 minutes. Complete shutdown permitted if code and ADA requirements are met.
Buildings with ≥4 elevators in a bank shall use destination dispatch or equivalent intelligent scheduling to minimize energy use

J_elevators_escalators.sf_note: DBI reviews elevator energy compliance during mechanical plan check. Elevator permits are separate from building permits in SF — coordinate with DBI Elevator Division.

K_process_boilers.description: Process boiler and steam systems (not space heating)

requirements.detail: Process boilers shall meet minimum efficiency per Table 140.9-K based on size and fuel type. Condensing boilers required where return water temperature permits.
Stack economizers or combustion air preheaters required for boilers ≥10 MMBtu/h input
Steam systems shall include steam trap monitoring capability. Annual steam trap survey required for systems with ≥20 traps.
Condensate return systems required for steam systems ≥15 psi where distance to boiler is ≤600 ft
Process ovens and furnaces shall be insulated to limit case temperature to ≤140°F above ambient during steady-state operation
Process heating equipment ≥2 MMBtu/h with exhaust temperature ≥350°F shall have heat recovery capable of preheating combustion air or process loads
Electric resistance process heating shall use highest practical voltage to minimize I²R distribution losses

applicable_to: All new nonresidential buildings with parking

requirements.detail: New nonresidential buildings shall provide EV charging infrastructure per Table 140.10-A. Percentage of spaces varies by building type and total parking count.
Electrical panel capacity and conduit routing shall be installed to serve future EV charging equipment even for 'EV-capable' (not 'EV-ready') spaces.
Buildings with ≥20 EV charging spaces shall have EV load management system (EVLMS) capable of distributing available power across charging stations.

M_EV_charging.sf_note: SF's local EV ordinance (Environment Code Chapter 4) may require MORE EV spaces than Title 24 minimums. Coordinate with SF Planning for local requirements.

N_pool_spa.description: Swimming pools, spas, and heated water features

requirements.detail: Heated pools and spas shall have covers with R-12 minimum insulation value. Automatic cover systems required for pools ≥1,000 sq ft surface area.
Pool pumps shall comply with DOE efficiency standards. Multi-speed or variable-speed pump motors required for pumps ≥1 HP.
Outdoor pools ≥1,000 sq ft shall be heated by solar thermal, heat pump, or waste heat recovery. Gas-fired heaters only as supplemental/backup.
Pool heating and filtration systems shall have time clock controls to limit operation during unoccupied periods

P_commercial_laundry.description: Commercial laundry and dry cleaning systems

requirements.detail: Commercial laundry water heating systems shall use ozone injection, heat pump water heating, or waste heat recovery where feasible
Commercial dryers with total capacity ≥100 lbs shall have dryer exhaust heat recovery systems
Commercial dryers shall have moisture sensing automatic shutoff controls

Q_water_treatment.description: Water treatment and process water systems

requirements.detail: Process water pumps ≥5 HP shall have variable-speed drives or multiple staging to match flow to load
Process water systems rejecting ≥500,000 Btu/h shall evaluate heat recovery for space heating or service water preheating
Commercial dishwashers, fryers, griddles, hot food holding cabinets, ice machines, ovens, and steam cookers shall be ENERGY STAR certified where an applicable ENERGY STAR specification exists
Pre-rinse spray valves shall have flow rate ≤1.28 GPM
Horticultural lighting systems shall have minimum efficacy of 1.9 µmol/J (PPF efficacy). LED required for new installations.
Supplemental lighting shall have photoperiod controls and daylight integration where natural light is available
Greenhouse HVAC systems shall use heat recovery for dehumidification rather than reheat where feasible

S_greenhouse.sf_note: Cannabis cultivation facilities in SF require additional permits from SF Office of Cannabis. Energy efficiency for cannabis operations may also be subject to local energy audit requirements.

T_misc_process.description: Miscellaneous process systems (catch-all for other process loads)
applicable_to: Any nonresidential building with process loads not covered by categories A through S

requirements.detail: All process motors ≥1 HP shall meet NEMA Premium efficiency or IE3 equivalent
Process pumps and fans ≥5 HP serving variable loads shall have variable frequency drives
Process loads ≥100 kW shall have dedicated energy metering for monitoring and benchmarking

prescriptive.description: Meet individual component requirements in Section 140.9 for each applicable process system. Most projects use this approach.
prescriptive.advantage: Straightforward, no energy modeling required for process systems
prescriptive.limitation: Cannot trade off between process systems — each must independently comply

performance.description: Include process loads in whole-building energy model (NRCC-PRF-01-E). Process energy can be traded against other building systems.
performance.advantage: Allows trade-offs (e.g., more efficient kitchen ventilation can offset less efficient lighting)
performance.limitation: Requires energy modeling expertise; process load inputs must be documented with manufacturer data

common_corrections.description: NRCC-PRC-E not included when project has process loads (especially restaurants and buildings with elevators)
common_corrections.frequency: Very common for restaurant and grocery projects
common_corrections.resolution: Complete NRCC-PRC-E for all applicable process systems. List each system category (A–T) that applies.

common_corrections.description: Commercial kitchen ventilation (Category A) not documented with hood types, exhaust rates, and makeup air calculations
common_corrections.resolution: Provide kitchen ventilation schedule showing hood type, duty rating, exhaust CFM, makeup air CFM, and DCV compliance for systems ≥5,000 CFM

common_corrections.description: Walk-in cooler/freezer insulation and motor requirements not documented (Category B)
common_corrections.frequency: Common for restaurant and grocery projects
common_corrections.resolution: Document wall/ceiling R-values, door closers, ECM motors, and anti-sweat heater controls for all walk-ins

common_corrections.description: Enclosed parking garage ventilation does not show CO sensor layout or demand control capability
common_corrections.frequency: Common for mixed-use buildings with underground parking
common_corrections.resolution: Provide CO sensor layout (1 per 5,000 sq ft min), fan VFD documentation, and DCV control sequence

common_corrections.description: Elevator cab lighting, ventilation, and standby mode requirements not documented
common_corrections.frequency: Moderate — often overlooked on smaller projects
common_corrections.resolution: Document elevator cab LED lighting, standby mode capability, and regenerative drive (if applicable)

common_corrections.description: EV-capable/EV-ready parking spaces not shown on plans or electrical documents
common_corrections.frequency: Common for new construction and major alterations with parking
common_corrections.resolution: Show EV space count per Table 140.10-A, conduit routing, and panel capacity on electrical plans

sf_specific_notes.detail: Process systems are reviewed during M-06 (Mechanical), M-07 (Plumbing), and M-08 (Energy) plan check stages depending on the system type. Missing PRC-E documentation triggers corrections that hold permit issuance.

Restaurant projects in SF require PRC-E documentation for Categories A (kitchen ventilation), B (walk-in coolers), and R (commercial appliances) at minimum. DPH food facility permit also requires ventilation review.
SF's AB-093 green building ordinance may require energy performance beyond Title 24 minimums for process systems in large buildings (≥25,000 sq ft).
SF's local EV ordinance (Environment Code Chapter 4) requires more EV-ready spaces than state minimums. SF Planning reviews EV compliance during site permit review.
Cannabis cultivation and manufacturing facilities have additional energy audit and efficiency requirements under SF Office of Cannabis regulations. Category S (greenhouse) requirements apply.

documents_to_add: Kitchen ventilation schedule (Category A — if restaurant/food service)
Walk-in cooler/freezer specifications (Category B — if food service)
CO sensor layout for garage ventilation (Category E — if enclosed parking)
EV charging infrastructure plan (Category M — if parking provided)

estimate_timeline.note: Projects with complex process systems (restaurants, labs, data centers) typically add 1-2 weeks to plan check timeline due to PRC-E review and potential corrections
